raw_comment:
What do you notice?

Legacy applicants and students with higher SES parents are more likely to be admitted to elite colleges.

What do you wonder?

What moderator or mediator variables are under the hood here? SES is not revealed on an application but how does 18 years of having parents with a higher SES impact the quality of a student's application?

How does this relate to you and your community?

Mississippi residents often stay in the state for college. Therefore, few Mississippi students have parents who attended one of these elite colleges. Also, the SES of Mississippi is relatively low. Does this make it unlikely for Mississippi students to get admitted to elite colleges? What makes a college elite and why are there no elite colleges in the south? What is the return on investment (ROI) on attending an elite college? 

Create a catchy headline that captures the graphâ€™s main idea.

"Cycles of Power & Privilege"
ace_sentences: Legacy applicants are more likely to be admitted to elite colleges.
Students who have parents with a higher socioeconomic status are more likely to be admitted to elite colleges.
I wonder which moderator variables exist.
I wonder which mediator variables exist.
Socioeconomic status is not revealed on an application.
A student can have parents with a higher socioeconomic status for 18 years.
I wonder how having parents with a higher socioeconomic status for 18 years impacts the quality of a student's application.
Mississippi residents often stay in Mississippi for college.
Therefore, few Mississippi students have parents who attended an elite college.
The socioeconomic status in Mississippi is relatively low.
I wonder if these facts make it unlikely that Mississippi students are admitted to elite colleges.
I wonder what makes a college elite.
I wonder why no elite colleges exist in the South.
I wonder what the return on investment is for attending an elite college.
The headline is: Cycles of Power and Privilege.
